captions.text:
00:06
COMM: For most comic-book fans, owning a Batmobile

is just a pipe dream. But here in Australia
one Batman fanatic has made the dream a reality.

By hand-building his own version of the iconic
vehicle.

00:19
ZAC: What makes this Batmobile different is,

it's street legal. Like I can take it down
and get groceries if i wanted to. The reaction
to the car has been insane.

00:27
BOY: It looks awesome!

00:34
COMM: Zac Mihajlovic started building his

replica four years ago with the help of his
very own Lucius Fox… Grandfather John Greene,

a retired engineer. During the two-year build,
the 29-year old was even able to get some

of the parts from the car used in the original
film.

00:48
ZAC: The Batmobile behind me is the 1989 Batmobile

and this was the Michael Keaton and Jack Nicholson.
It's go adjustable suspension, it's got a

working afterburner, which is from the film,
no machine gun sadly, no grappling hooks,

no bombs that come out the wheel but pretty
much beyond that… yeah it's pretty close.

01:08
COMM: There are thought to be 10 other replicas

of the 1989 Batmobile but Zac believes he's
the only one that can legally driven on the
public roads.

01:17
ZAC: The first time I took it out was definitely

an experience. I was on the freeway on the
way to the gold coast and there was this noise

and I thought something was wrong with the
car. It's actually the news helicopter from

channel 9 that chased me down the freeway.
That was pretty memorable.

01:33
COMM: And not surprisingly the replica has
won him plenty of admires, including the ladies.

01:37
ANNABELLA: My names Annabella Leone and I'm

dating Batman. We've been dating for about
four years and can I just say I was with him

two years prior to the Batmobile. That's my
seat there, the passenger seat and if any
girl out there wants it, I swear to god, dead.

01:51
COMM: And Zac has also had this fair share
of bizarre requests

01:54
ZAC: I've had a couple ring me up and say

I know this is gonna sound weird but we want
to christen the car, so to speak. And I sort

of said I'm not really interested and they
said we'll pay what you want! And we'll bring

plastic sheets and I'm like you've just made
that worse, so no thanks.

02:13
COMM: Businessmen from across the world have

offered Zac big bucks for the Batmobile, but
he has decided to use his powers for good

by teaming up with the Make-a-Wish foundation.
who make dreams come true for terminally-ill
children.

02:25
COMM: Today he's using his comic-book car
to impress families at the local shops.

02:30
ZAC: It's a brilliant, brilliant charity charity

because it gives kids sadly their dying wish.
I dress up as Batman and I surprise the kids

sometimes. It's knocking on someones door.
Obviously organised. Some of them run for

their lives and it takes a bit of warming
up to get them back into, into the Batmobile.
But some are just super pumped.

02:51
COMM: Over the last three years Zac has helped

more than 40 children and has no plans to
stop.

02:56
COMM: While he may not be using the Batmobile

to fight off the Joker or The Penguin. In
the eyes of many, he's very much a hero.

title: Real Life Batmobile: Man Spends Two Years Building Iconic 1989 Car

comments.author: oavesso

comments.text:
Zac Mihajlovic aus Australien hat zwei Jahre seiner Freizeit damit 
verbracht ein Batmobil zu bauen, , das perfekt wie das Original aussieht, 
Feuer aus dem Auspuff bläst und sogar für die Straße zugelassen ist. 
Natürlich wollten es ihm schon Leute für jede Menge Geld abkaufen, aber er 
behält es lieber selbst und arbeitet mit der Make-A-Wish-Foundation 
zusammen, um kranken Kindern den Wunsch zu erfüllen, mal im Batmobil 
rumzudüsen. Cool ...﻿
